name: isophthalamide
source: Beilstein F. K.; Beilsteins Handbuch der Organischen Chemie. Springer; Berlin; 1972.

name: isophthalamide
source: Beilstein F. K.; Beilsteins Handbuch der Organischen Chemie. Springer; Berlin; 1972.
Reason: The basic unit for isophthalamide is benzene, which has a melting point around 5.5°C. The amide groups in isophthalamide greatly increase the melting point because of strong hydrogen bonding and resonance stability: each amide group can increase the melting point by approximately 180-200°C due to these intermolecular forces. There are two amide groups in isophthalamide. Additionally, the presence of the rigid aromatic ring structure also contributes to an increased melting point, albeit to a lesser extent than the amide groups, let's approximate this to +20°C. Combining these considerations, the prediction for the melting point of isophthalamide can be calculated.
Prediction: 5.5 (base benzene) + 180 (1st amide group) + 180 (2nd amide group) + 20 (aromatic stability) = 385.5°C
